150604298.review:
Cities: Skylines stands out as the premier gaming strategy of its kind for several compelling reasons, making it a true gem in the city-building genre.

First and foremost, the game offers an unparalleled level of realism and detail in city simulation. The attention to intricacies, from traffic flow dynamics to citizen behavior, creates a remarkably immersive experience. The game's robust engine allows players to craft cities with a level of intricacy that is both challenging and rewarding.

One of the game's key strengths lies in its flexibility and customization options. Cities: Skylines provides an extensive toolkit for players to design and shape their urban landscapes. The modding community further enhances this aspect, allowing for an almost limitless range of possibilities. Whether you want to recreate a real-world city or unleash your creativity with fantastical designs, the game accommodates it all.

The game's emphasis on urban planning and management is another standout feature. Balancing the needs of your citizens, managing resources, and solving intricate logistical challenges provide a deep and satisfying gameplay experience. The economic and civic systems are well-designed, offering a delicate balance that keeps players engaged as they strive to create thriving metropolises.

150335812.review:
[h1]Quick Review[/h1]
I purchased this as part of a Humble Bundle at some point several years ago, and have been quite pleased with it.  This bundle also included the "Snowfall" and "Natural Disasters" DLCs, which I like (particularly Snowfall).  It's great for designing and building a city, particularly if you enjoy traffic management.

So for those of you who don't want to read further:
Game good, but wait for sale.

[h1]Full Details[/h1]

[h2]The Good[/h2]

There are several things about Cities: Skylines that I quite enjoy.

The first is depth.  Compared to other city builders I've played (most of which are, admittedly, archaic by today's standards), it gives you a LOT of options.  Need to generate power?  Well, you can use Wind or Coal early on, but later you can use Solar, Hydroelectric, Nuclear, or Oil.  Need to build a neighborhood?  You've got half a dozen two-lane road options to play with.  Excessive traffic?  Time to add public transport.  Now, do you want buses, a metro, train stations, or even a railroad?  You have lots of options.  I like that.

The second is the game's performance.  Specifically, how remarkably stable it is, even with a ton of moving parts.  Cities: Skylines renders a ton of cars, trucks, and pedestrians.  However, despite this, my game hasn't suffered significantly.  Admittedly, I have to run the game on fairly low settings because my computer is a bit of a potato by today's standards, but I'm still quite impressed.

A third would be the workshop community.  There are a lot of mods and assets out there.  Like a [b][i] lot [/b][/i] of mods.  There are thousands of mods, ranging in scope from simply adding a new type of highway, to [i] completely overhauling core game mechanics [/i].  It's a bit overwhelming, but still quite enjoyable to peruse.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]

For all the good, though, there is a bit of bad.  Okay, a bit more than just a bit of bad.  It can be frustrating at times, but so can a lot of other games.

The first, and biggest, bad thing about the game is the lane mechanics.  Frankly, they're a bit idiotic sometimes.  Trying to turn a six-lane road into a divided highway to try to optimize an interchange?  Well, you'd think the two highways would just cleanly connect, right?  No; for some reason, you'll get a turn lane on the incoming highway, and there's no way to change that in game.  This was changed in C:S2, if memory serves, and there was a mod that allowed players to do that, but it appears that mod hasn't been updated in over a year, unfortunately.

The second issue I have with the game is, admittedly, a minor gripe with regards to pollution.  Specifically, how there isn't really a way to reduce air pollution.  There are a number of policies you can invoke to do things like improve the health of citizens at the cost of happiness by banning smoking, or reduce fire risks at the cost of income by providing free smoke detectors.  I feel like there should be a policy that reduces air pollution, or some other sort of option.  This could be resolved in one of the DLCs I don't own (which I will likely pick up when they next go on sale), but regardless, it's a minor gripe of mine.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Yes, this is a good game.  It's not as gorgeous as the new C:S2, but C:S is still a good game, worthy of the sequel that recently released.

150121510.review:
I love this game and it quickly become the occupier of almost all of my free time (and even some of my not-free time, which can be problematic). That said, there are some issues you should know before getting into it.

The Bad:

The BASE vanilla game is pretty barren with little creativity to be incorporated beyond how you layout the city. Assets are limited and there are a lot of QoL issues with the interface and amount of control you have over things.
The expansions, while adding many new design options and freedoms to certain aspects, are priced in a way that restricts their access. All of the good expansions coming in at $15/pop means that to really get the best vanilla experience, you will need to drop $150+ into it.

The Good:

The community for this game is Top Tier and heavily dedicated. Finding answers to questions and other forms of assistance is incredibly easy. There is a plethora of content creators that focus on the game that are both entertaining and focus on a variety of aspects and approaches to the game.
As an extension, the available free mods for this game is ENDLESS adding both QoL tools that I almost cannot play without at this point (as it is becoming more evident as I play CS2), but also custom assets upon assets to really add character and life to your city.

This is one of those situations where community support is what set this game apart from all other comparable games of the genre. It is because of this I am not concerned about the rocky start CS2 has had. The community will be there for it as well.

I used to play RCT1 on my old HP Pavilion running Vista back when I was little, so when I found out I liked this game, it wasn't that surprising. It's a very fun and in-depth game, and with the countless mods available, you can fine-tune it however you like. 

However, I do have some issues with it.

1. You are not running this game on the minimum hardware requirements, especially with the DLC and mods. This isn't really a fault of the devs, but I can barely run it on my machine with a i5-10400, a 1080, and 16 GB of RAM without crashing. 

2. The game can be kinda frustrating played vanilla. TM:PE, NetExtensions2, and Network Anarchy are almost a requirement, especially when you're dealing with interchanges and roundabouts.

3. The DLC has some things that would be useful in the base game. Locking the two-laned highways and the bike lanes behind DLC isn't great.

Those three things don't stop me from playing this game or rating it positively.

TL;DR you need a beefy machine, mods, and DLC to enjoy it, but you'll definitely enjoy it if you do.

149901141.review:
A detailed and lasting realistic city builder who needs both shelling out on many DLCs and investing quite some time into a single city to really start to shine, which, if you like me prefer focusing on early building up not late game optimizations may strongly disappoint you.

Now, generally this one runs legit well, allows to create pretty convincing cities and is super moddable so you can either just add some visual flair or strongly alter the experience. Like one youtuber I really like turns this into a pretty sandbox with no financial concerns and very freeform world altering to tell a story of whole made up region with it's own history and landmarks, and it's very relaxing to watch in progress. Vanilla is pretty expansive too with at least some bigger "must-have" DLCs bought, and for a first if not too long play-trough without them it all feels really cool and detailed too, though the game is like 8 years old by now, so it doesn't look that super closer up, at least without putting effort plopping down decor and other details yourself to make it appear nicer.

Now thing is, this one starts you off with really limited options at start and you have to achieve population goals to expand further on. So often I'd end up with stages of the game where I just keep plopping down additional streets and amenities to support them to reach those numbers. And this whole system feels so much more restrictive than say the venerable SimCity 4 - and I get the desire to keep things accessible from start and let player focus only on current necessities, but as it's set up it's all very restrictive, and I won't lie free unrestricted play can indeed introduce some choice paralysis when you're still inexperienced. I wish there was some system to keep game start more varied and giving different priorities and strongly distinct choices, like allowing you to plop down one way ahead from progression structure like electric dam or advanced power plant while starting off town as naturally having emerged from town of power plant personnel and you'd have some power provision obligations to focus on fulfilling.

It's fine, not for me or anyone who like me expects an as engaging early as late game, but seeing how at the moment Skylines II is underperforming while making people's GPUs overperform this may remain the premier realistic city builder for quite some time.

149831612.review:
Cities: Skylines is hands down one of the best city-building games I've ever played. From the moment I started constructing my first road, I was hooked. This game is a delightful urban planning playground that has provided me with countless hours of fun.

One of the standout features is the sheer level of detail and realism. The graphics are stunning, and the attention to small details like traffic flow, citizen needs, and city aesthetics is incredibly impressive. It really feels like you're in charge of your very own thriving metropolis.

The game's flexibility is a big selling point. You can choose to play in a variety of maps, each with its own unique challenges, and the modding community is active and creative, offering a plethora of custom assets and modifications. This means you can tailor your city-building experience to your liking, whether you want to create a sprawling metropolis or a cozy, picturesque town.

The gameplay is intuitive and engaging. The way the game guides you through the intricacies of city planning while allowing you the freedom to experiment and make mistakes is commendable. It's a perfect balance between accessible for newcomers and deep enough to satisfy the most seasoned city-building veterans.

The satisfaction of watching your city grow and evolve is incredibly rewarding. You'll find yourself constantly improving your infrastructure, managing budgets, and responding to the needs of your citizens. Whether it's solving traffic jams or ensuring a steady water supply, every challenge is a chance to learn and grow.

One aspect that sets Cities: Skylines apart from other city-building games is the developer's commitment to ongoing support and updates. They have a strong track record of listening to the community and implementing changes that enhance the gameplay. It's clear that they genuinely care about their game and their players.

In short, Cities: Skylines is a city-building dream come true. It's a game that lets you unleash your creativity and inner urban planner. The sense of achievement and pride you'll feel as your city flourishes is unparalleled. Whether you're a fan of the genre or a newcomer, I wholeheartedly recommend giving this game a try. It's worth every penny and countless hours of your time. Happy city building!

149740166.review:
A classic city builder. Looks perfectly fine today, and the extensive modding community can allow you to boost the graphics up to insane levels. It's super fun to manage your city and expand. The mechanics are good with a few big issues. 

There are some issues with the game that require mods if you want to fix/improve. And there are some features that the game is practically begging to have. This is why the modding community is so important for Cities: Skylines. 

Here are some things to be aware of before buying Cities Skylines:
-The game is decently easy to learn, and very hard to get good at. This is because to have a high population city that functions well, you need to learn some actual real life city planning knowledge. Or else the traffic be too much, and your whole city will fall apart. There are plenty of great content creators who can help with with this though.
-A few mechanics like road building can be quite frustrating at times with things not working how you'd expect. This can be fixed by mods such as Network Anarchy, but without mods, it can sometimes be a struggle.
-The DLC plan for this game is in short, absurd. Many of them seem essential as the features they provide are huge upgrades to the game, but each of them costs 13-15 dollars. I do not own all of them (I'm missing 1 or 2), and it still cost me $155 + the price of getting the game. This is way too expensive, and it locks a lot of the best aspects of the game behind a paywall.

Despite its flaws, I adore this game and love building elaborate cities. If you buy this game, expect to spend many hours working on your cities as you watch them grow into massive metropolises.

It pains me to write this review, I loved this game, but for the past 2 years it has been unplayable for me. 

Now if you have a decently spec'ed PC (10XX GTX, 16GB of RAM) or better, you will be able to enjoy the *base game* and *some* of the DLC, but if you want to experience the full game with all, or even *most* DLC, nothing less than 32GB RAM will be enough. Even with mods that help with compressing textures and getting more out of your RAM are no longer enough. There are at least 2 DLCs in my library (Airports, and Plazas & Promenades) that I have not been able to play AT ALL, and given the large number of hours I have logged I'll never be able to refund them. The game is not very well optimized and even with DLCs unloaded the game still runs poorly without mods.

So BEWARE, the specs listed in here on the store page are for the BASE GAME only, and even then the game will have issues that are best resolved with community patches. Please Paradox fix this game so I can play all of my DLCs! (I'm not holding my breath given the state of Cities Skylines 2 which appears to be less optimized than its predecessor.)

Buggy & performance clunky. 

$300+ worth of DLCs, $150 of which is required for game mechanics. I don't mind paying for DLCs that fund development of the game mechanics, but after 3-5 years and still charging the same price... it's like a slap in the face for any returning players or new players. Most of which the DLCs are either mixed or negative reviews. Majority of players already know a game isn't worth hundreds of dollars, and this game doesn't even come close to that worth. Which then makes you realize the mods are really just overpriced digital crap.

Even after you pay for all the creator content, mods are still essentially required to improve the quality of the game. In some regards, mods make the game playable due to the number of limitations & restrictions. You'll even need a mod loader in some cases, which I would recommend "Skyve" for also checking for compatibility & known issues with mods.

For the overall price, the game is a BIG disappointment, and likely won't even bother with City: Skylines 2 (especially after seeing the bug reports & reviews).

149620191.review:
Can't recommend this game in good faith-

Not to sound paradoxical (pun intended), but I do like this game very much- I think what the SimCity games developed back in the day, this game itself has near perfected for the most part. The UI is pretty intuitive, the different simulation mechanics of the city are fun, decently mod/workshop friendly, and it is a very visually lovely and appealing game.

 What I did not like was the DLC model that Paradox has implemented for this game, and many of their other games as well from what I've heard and seen. Improvements to mechanics to fix some of the short-comings of the base game, along with the standard bevy of new buildings and features, are all sparsed out in the overwhelming selection of purchasable DLC. 

A few problems I have with it here- The shear amount of purchase modules they have introduced in and of itself is pretty damn ridiculous. Also, new features are great for extra fun or to extend the life of the game. But tweaking the base mechanics, in what should have so obviously been provided with updates to the base game? Meh. 

Additionally, the game is does allow modding, but it can cause functionality issues depending on what DLC that you do or don't have.  This all can add up the cost of this game dramatically. Feels a bit deceptive or even unethical in my opinion.

Ok, I'm getting off my soapbox now, that is all.

Title: An In-depth Look at "Cities: Skylines" and its Numerous Expansions

"Cities: Skylines" is more than just a game; it's an extensive platform for those who revel in the challenges of urban planning. With its numerous DLCs (Downloadable Content), it has carved a firm place in the hearts of its community, offering an almost inexhaustible palette of possibilities for creative minds. Below is a comprehensive review of the game and its expansions, shedding light on both the positive and negative aspects.

1. **Gameplay and Graphics**:
   - **Gameplay**: "Cities: Skylines" offers a balanced mix of challenge and freedom. The core mechanics of the game, such as traffic planning and satisfying citizens' needs, are demanding but not overwhelming. The expansions enrich the gameplay in a variety of ways, whether it's by adding new building types, introducing day-night cycles, or allowing the creation of special districts.
   - **Graphics**: The graphical representation is appealing and provides enough details to immerse players in the world without losing clarity.

2. **Story and Narrative**:
   - "Cities: Skylines" does not follow a prescribed narrative but gives players the freedom to tell their own story through the construction and development of their city.

3. **Expansions (DLCs)**:
   - **Positive Aspects**:
     - **Parklife**: This expansion enables players to build their own parks, zoos, or amusement parks, and provides more micro-management options, visually enhancing the city[39†(Netzpiloten)].
     - **After Dark**: Adds a day-night transition and new possibilities for commercial areas to attract tourists or enliven the nightlife[39†(Netzpiloten)][50†(Gamers Decide)].
     - **Snowfall**: Introduces a new snow theme and weather options, posing new challenges for urban planning[50†(Gamers Decide)].
   - **Negative Aspects**:
     - Some players find "Natural Disasters" to burden the game with unnecessary challenges and "Industries" to be very unrealistic[45†(Steam Community)].
     - The "After Dark" expansion is seen as very basic and many believe its features should have been included in the main game from the start[50†(Gamers Decide)].

4. **Rating of DLCs**:
   - There is a plethora of DLCs, some of which, like "After Dark" and "Snowfall," receive mixed reviews, while others like "Parklife" are more positively received[39†(Netzpiloten)][50†(Gamers Decide)].

5. **Overall Rating**:
   - "Cities: Skylines" and its expansions offer a rich and rewarding experience for anyone interested in urban planning and management. The variety of DLCs allows players to tailor their experience to their liking, though some expansions might not offer the desired value to everyone.

"Cities: Skylines" is an impressive package further enhanced by its DLCs. Each expansion brings new elements and challenges to the game, enriching the overall experience and significantly increasing the replay value.

Cities: Skylines is a masterclass in city-building and urban management, offering players an engaging and immersive experience that sets the gold standard for the genre. Developed by Colossal Order, this game is not just a city builder; it's a dynamic, living world where your imagination is the only limit.

From the moment you begin your city-building journey, you are greeted with an expansive canvas of possibilities. The attention to detail in the game's graphics, coupled with a beautifully rendered world, allows you to create a city that is not only functional but visually stunning. The variety of buildings, roads, and landscapes at your disposal enables you to design a city that reflects your creativity and vision.

One of Cities: Skylines' standout features is its remarkable depth. The game offers an intricate and intuitive city-building system that caters to both newcomers and seasoned players. The mechanics are easy to grasp, yet complex enough to challenge even the most experienced urban planners. The game's educational aspect, with tutorials and guides, makes it accessible for those new to the genre.

The freedom to shape your city is truly empowering. You can decide everything, from zoning, infrastructure, and public services to transportation, industry, and policies. This level of control allows for endless possibilities in city design, and you'll find yourself constantly optimizing and experimenting to create the most efficient and beautiful city.

The sense of realism in Cities: Skylines is outstanding. Traffic management is a central element, and the game's AI-driven traffic system is both impressive and challenging. Solving traffic problems and designing efficient road networks add a layer of strategy to the gameplay.

The game's expansion packs and mod support further extend its replayability. Whether you want to expand your city with new content or personalize your experience with user-generated mods, the game's community and developers provide ample support for players to tailor their cities to their liking.

Cities: Skylines' attention to detail extends to the residents of your city. You'll witness citizens going about their daily lives, and their demands and happiness contribute to the complexity of your urban planning. Ensuring the well-being of your population adds depth to the gameplay, making the game more than just a simulation of roads and buildings.

The game's visuals and audio are also exceptional. The soundtrack is soothing and matches the game's calming pace, while the sound effects and animations breathe life into your city.

In conclusion, Cities: Skylines is a true gem in the city-building genre, offering an authentic and intricate urban management experience. It combines creativity, strategy, and realism to deliver a game that is both satisfying and endlessly replayable. Whether you're a fan of the genre or just curious to try your hand at urban planning, Cities: Skylines is a must-play title that will keep you engrossed in crafting the city of your dreams for hours on end. It's a triumph of city-building simulation and a testament to the art of urban planning in gaming.

Imagine constructing poorly designed cities and trying to tax as much as possible but enjoying doing it. That's the magic of Cities: Skylines. This city-building simulation game has earned its reputation, and you'll quickly understand why it's loved by many.

Whether you're embarking on your very first urban planning adventure or diving into Cities: Skylines II, this game offers many experiences. From designing your metropolis to dealing with perpetual traffic jams, every moment is engaging. 

The game's strength lies in its modding support, which fuels endless creativity. With a thriving modding community, there's a wealth of user-generated content, from realistic landmarks to gameplay improvements. Paradox Interactive's DLC policy has been divisive, but in my view, the content is often well worth the price.

Cities: Skylines doesn't just entertain; it educates. As your cities evolve from chaotic towns to thriving metropolises, you'll learn valuable skills in city planning and management. It's a perpetual challenge, and the learning curve is well-balanced, letting you tailor the experience to your preferences.

With unrelenting support from Paradox, this game keeps getting better. The potential to expand and enhance your city-building experience is limitless. The game teaches you to embrace creativity, making every hour invested worth it.

Cities: Skylines has been a testament to how a city simulator can become a lifelong passion. As we await Cities: Skylines II, the legacy of this game will undoubtedly live on, offering countless hours of creative and educational enjoyment.

So far...OK. 

System Specs:
Intel Core i7-4790K
GeForce RTX 3080 12GB
16GB Ram
OS: Linux Mint - with Proton Experimental

I'm running at 3440x1440 with most settings on HIGH and have not had any real issues. Occasionally there will be a half second  pause (I think as it auto saves) but I've had zero crashes. It absolutely turns my system into a space heater though. I've played a couple of cities up to the 50K citizen number and it's still running smoothly. 


Game wise I'm missing a lot of the stuff that I got from mods, but I'm sure those will come in good time. It does feel a little more barren than CS1, but again you can't compare this against an 8 year old release with tons of DLC and mods. I like some of the stuff that got built in such as the grid layout and parallel road tools. I also like that the snapping of roads and rail allow for more narrow angles which makes things look more realistic. There are some hiccups at times where on uneven terrain buildings won't connect to the power or water utilities, but that's pretty minor. 

Reading through other reviews it seems I have been lucky, but based on my initial feelings I'm happy with it.

148879104.review:
Over the years the base game has gotten many improvements via patches, and at present is an excellent gateway into the wealth of additional content the developers have made throughout this titles lifespan. The base game is certainly worth it, especially with the flop that Slylines 2's launch has been. So yeah, weirdly enough I recommend the original, this game, over the sequel if you're looking to get into this type of game right now.

By no means do you need all the DLC to have a good time. Start with the base game, get to know how things work, and then branch out into whatever DLC looks most interesting to you if you should so desire.

Final note: while Skylines 1 isn't perfect, it's performance is and always has been pretty good in my experience. I've played the game on various different PC setups ranging from low to upper mid-range, and while performance will slow as you expand, it never got to the point where the game felt unplayable. Many will claim this game can run on a potato, and at this point that's probably true.

148753832.review:
Cities: Skylines, or as I like to call it, "The Mayor Simulator," is the only game where you can make all the terrible decisions you wish your actual politicians wouldn't. It's like playing with your own little dollhouse, except instead of dolls, you've got an entire city to manipulate.

You'll start with good intentions, planning neat grids and efficient road systems, but before you know it, your city's traffic is more tangled than your headphones after a day in your pocket. And don't get me started on water management; it's like trying to solve a Rubik's Cube blindfolded!

But it's not all chaos and frustration; it's also an urban planner's dream come true. You can make a thriving metropolis with glittering skyscrapers and lush parks, or you can create a dystopian nightmare with sewage flooding the streets and power outages every five minutes.

The best part is watching your citizens' complaints flood in faster than your sewer system failures. "Not enough workers," they'll cry as you bulldoze their homes to make room for another shopping mall. And they still want more parks, even if it means the destruction of the last remaining forest in your city.

So, if you've ever thought, "I could do a better job running this city," Cities: Skylines is the place to put your mayoral prowess to the test. Just remember, it's all fun and games until your city burns to the ground because you forgot to build a fire department.

148353630.review:
Cities: Skylines, the city-building simulation game, thrives on its robust modding features, keeping players like myself engaged for over 2000 hours. This game's unique charm lies in its extensive modding community, which continually expands and enhances the experience.

The modding scene is a standout feature, offering diverse content, from realistic landmarks to gameplay improvements. The depth and quality of user-generated content are astounding, making customization a breeze.

Despite spending thousands of hours, Cities: Skylines never gets old. It's a perpetual challenge, encouraging you to refine your cities. The learning curve is well-balanced, allowing you to tailor the experience to your liking.

In over 2000 hours, my cities have transformed from chaotic towns to thriving metropolises. The game's city planning and management elements teach valuable skills, creating an engaging and educational experience.

In summary, Cities: Skylines, with its modding support and unending creativity, remains a captivating city-building game that continues to inspire and educate, making every hour invested well worth it.

148106832.review:
Doing a review esp. with City Skylines 2 coming out it's honestly amazing how much stuff was missing from this game and yet it completely revolutionized a genre that was dying for the last 10 years before it released.

This game does so much right (esp. when you have some of the most essential DLCs) and it can be extremely addicting. That being said, the flaws are noticeable and even mods can't really fix all problems. The entity limits make the very late game extremely frustrating, you have to plan a lot of your designs around the limits of the game and stuff can start to randomly break.

There is also the problem with DLCs not being dependent on each other creating huge gaps in the quality of the game. For example, the industries DLC fixes the extremely stale and boring vanilla industry but this doesn't affect other DLC industries that aren't part of the base game because they can't expect you to have the industries DLC.

The last problem I want to mention are the unrealistic car and street systems in the game. While in development they realized that car dependent cities are such a nightmare to city planning and the game wouldn't be fun if they made it a bit more realistic and they do have some DLCs that touch on that but overall this game heavily favours cars. Vehicular transport is absolutely OP which makes great city planning even more frustrating as you're often giving up the ease of just using the broken and unrealistic cars that don't even need to park anywhere and just despawn when they get stuck in traffic compared to the more realistic public transport in the game.

And yet, this game is a 9.9/10. The fact that there even is this much hype around City Skylines 2 showcases the willingness of the developers to touch on these issues that were unfixable in city skylines 1 for various reasons and even if modern Paradox + Colossal can be scummy with their DLCs at times, this game deserves to be such a success, if it wasn't for city skylines 1 the entire genre of city builders might have honestly been dead at this point. It showcased how much potential there still was in city builders at a time where Simcity was at the lowest point it ever was and the chance of never getting a new simcity felt high.

City Skylines 1 will most likely also stay the bigger and more feature-rich game for quite some time so if you ever get the chance to buy it for really cheap, the graphics and gameplay honestly still hold up, even 7 years after release.

If you are however looking for a solid foundation that will most definitely carry this franchise for another 7 years, I'd wait for City Skylines 2 and buy that. 

Edit after City Skylines 2 came out: I'd honestly recommend city skylines 1 over 2 right now. Give City Skylines 2 a few months (preferably even a year) so they can fix the really obnoxious problems

147953728.review: I played "SimCity" for many years and through many iterations.  Cities Skylines is superior in so many ways. Not the least of which is that it is not created by Electronic Arts.  The level of detail is fantastic and Mods make most of the mundane or difficult building tasks manageable if not easy.  The greatest pitfall (which exists in all city builder simulations) is the mismatch between the concept of "city growth time" and the concept of time with regards to the average citizen.  There are multiple time bases in existence in order for the game to be playable, but only one is represented on the UI.  Examples of this dichotomy would be a citizen that takes 8 days to walk 3 city blocks, a high density commercial building that goes up in 2 days and traffic jams that last for weeks.  With that said, I leave it to you to discover your own examples.  The game can be a resource hog on your p.c., but it can also be very entertaining if you're willing to disregard the concept of time.  Judging by the amount of hours I've played and the # of DLC's I have, I guess I have decided to overlook time.  Hell, all I'm doing is killing it anyway!

147891544.review:
Cities: Skylines is a masterpiece in city-building simulation games. Developed by Paradox Interactive, this game offers a level of depth and detail that's truly remarkable. As a dedicated player of city management titles, I can confidently say that Cities: Skylines stands out as one of the best in the genre.

One of the game's most impressive aspects is its sheer scale. You have the freedom to build sprawling metropolises or quaint, efficient towns, and the game handles both with ease. The attention to detail in every aspect of city planning is staggering; from road networks and public transportation to managing resources like water and electricity, it all feels incredibly realistic.

The modding community for Cities: Skylines is also worth noting. The game supports a plethora of user-created content, allowing you to tailor your city-building experience to your exact preferences. Whether it's adding new buildings, customizing traffic behavior, or enhancing aesthetics, the possibilities are endless.

Moreover, the game's graphics are stunning, and the level of immersion it provides is unmatched. Watching your city grow and evolve over time is immensely satisfying. The soundtrack complements the gameplay perfectly, creating an atmosphere that keeps you engaged for hours on end.

In conclusion, Cities: Skylines is a testament to the potential of city-building simulation games. Its meticulous attention to detail, modding community support, and overall gameplay experience make it a must-play for anyone with a passion for urban planning and management. If you're looking for a game that will provide countless hours of strategic fun and creativity, look no further than Cities: Skylines.

147825788.review:
Cities: Skylines, folks, is like the SimCity that finally grew up and got its driver's license – it's the full-blown city simulation experience you've been dreaming of!

The developers here have gone all-in on city simulation, especially when it comes to traffic. It's like they've earned honorary degrees in traffic management – you can design your transport system with the precision of a mad scientist, and watch those pixelated citizens actually use it! It's like a tiny, virtual traffic ballet, and you're the puppeteer pulling all the strings.

But here's the twist – it's almost like Cities: Skylines has an addiction to downloadable content (DLC). There are so many DLCs that it feels like they're multiplying faster than rabbits in a carrot farm. Some of these DLCs are game-changers, while others are like that one extra topping on a pizza that nobody asked for. The sheer quantity of DLCs can be a little overwhelming, like trying to eat an entire cake in one sitting – it's delicious, but at some point, you're wondering if you've bitten off more than you can chew.

So, if you're ready to dive into the urban jungle of Cities: Skylines, just remember to pace yourself with those DLCs – or else you might end up with more content than you know what to do with, like a city planner with too many blueprints and not enough coffee!

147427136.review:
I cannot believe I have gone this long without reviewing the original Cities Skylines. This is by and far the best city builder to ever be released, taking the title from SimCity and lofting it into the air with glee. Sadly, the game is now settling down for a long deserved retirement with the release of it's sequel title just round the corner, but you cannot go wrong with picking this up on a cheap deal to tide you over for the release of CSky 2.

Put simply, the developers saw what went wrong with Simcity's most recent incarnation and appealed to what players wanted. Big cities, living cities, cities that you can make your own and extend further with mods, cities that you can play offline, sit back and watch the ant farm mill about or destroy the entire lot with comets and tsunamis. That said, the disaster system is quite janky and doesn't quite work, but many turn it off and just let their cities grow. 

Once Cities Skylines 2 is released I am expecting this title to lay down in the long grass unless something goes terribly wrong with the sequel, in which case I could see this game having longevity for another decade or more. Either way it has it's place in the hall of video game classics.

147193671.review:
[h3] Cities: Skylines: A Thriving Metropolis of Modding Excellence [/h3] 

Cities: Skylines, the urban planning simulator from Colossal Order, has stood the test of time thanks to its thriving modding community. While the game has received a steady stream of DLC content, some of which could arguably be included in the base game, it's the modders who have truly elevated Cities: Skylines to greatness.

I will also commend the dedication of Colossal Order in supporting this game for such an extended period. While the continuous influx of DLC has been both a blessing and a curse, it's clear that the developers have shown a commitment to enhancing the experience for players. However, the cost of accumulating all the DLC can be quite substantial, leaving players wishing for a more inclusive base game.

Unfortunately, Cities: Skylines does suffer from a few drawbacks. One glaring issue is its poor game optimization, which can lead to performance problems on lower-end systems. Additionally, the base road tools leave much to be desired, often making road layout and design a frustrating experience - but as mention this and many other things are often fixed or made more accessible by the modding community. 

Nevertheless, Cities: Skylines remains a solid and enjoyable experience. Its vast, open sandbox provides endless opportunities for creativity, and its modding community has brought an astonishing array of custom content, from new buildings and assets to gameplay enhancements and quality-of-life improvements. The game's longevity is a testament to its enduring appeal, and it's more than playable for many years to come.

For those interested in diving into Cities: Skylines, it's wise to wait for sales, as the game frequently goes on discount, making it a more affordable investment. The value you'll get out of it, especially with the vast library of user-created mods available, is well worth the price.

As I reflect on Cities: Skylines' impressive journey, there's also reason to look forward to the future. With Cities: Skylines 2 on the horizon, I can only hope that Colossal Order will learn from the past and address the optimization and design issues, while still nurturing the vibrant modding community that has made this game a true city-building gem. Until then, for both veterans and newcomers, Cities: Skylines remains a must-play title in the genre, ensuring countless hours of urban planning enjoyment.

147187974.review:
This is a very well designed city building simulation, probably the only one worth playing on Steam.

The main mechanics of the game are very similar with SimCity's. I would say that the main challenge is the traffic and because of that you have to be a clever city planner and watch a lot of videos about it, made by many mostly funny and talented streamers.

It's a real joy to see how a small village grows and becomes a huge modern big city, with parks, industrial chains, touristic and entertainment zones, trains, airports and even monuments.

I don't think that I've played this game even once without mods. It's that kind of game. Never gets old because you can always find something new to try in your citadel.

Pros:
- very satisfying progress of your city
- beautiful and challenging (to plan a huge city) at the same time
- never gets old cause has mods support
- huge variety of buildings and gameplay style. You can build small villages everywhere or big cities full of high-rise buildings
- you can find anything you want to put in your city in workshop

Cons:
- the game can lag after you have a really huge city and I don't think there's anything you can do beside starting a new game.

147082777.review:
es un simulador de construcción de ciudades que ha sido ampliamente elogiado por su profundidad y capacidad para brindar a los jugadores el control total sobre la planificación y gestión de su propia metrópolis. Aquí tienes una reseña del juego:

Cities: Skylines es un título que te coloca en el asiento del alcalde y te desafía a construir y gestionar una ciudad desde cero. Desde el momento en que comienzas a trazar carreteras y zonificar áreas residenciales, te encuentras inmerso en un mundo de planificación urbana y toma de decisiones estratégicas.

Uno de los aspectos más destacados de Cities: Skylines es su capacidad para ofrecer una experiencia profundamente personalizada. Puedes diseñar cada aspecto de tu ciudad, desde la disposición de las carreteras hasta la gestión de servicios públicos como agua, electricidad y saneamiento. La capacidad de modificación y personalización a través de mods y contenido personalizado amplía aún más las posibilidades, lo que permite a los jugadores crear ciudades verdaderamente únicas.

La gestión económica y de recursos es fundamental en el juego, y tomar decisiones financieras sólidas es esencial para el crecimiento y la prosperidad de tu ciudad. La satisfacción de tus ciudadanos y su crecimiento poblacional dependen en gran medida de tu capacidad para proporcionar servicios eficientes y mantener el equilibrio financiero.

Los gráficos y la atención al detalle en Cities: Skylines son impresionantes. Cada edificio, cada vehículo y cada ciudadano están cuidadosamente diseñados, lo que contribuye a crear una ciudad vibrante y realista.

Sin embargo, algunos jugadores pueden encontrar que la curva de aprendizaje es empinada, ya que gestionar todos los aspectos de una ciudad puede ser abrumador al principio. Además, en ciertos momentos, el tráfico puede volverse problemático y requerir soluciones creativas.
